title: BMR Calculator (Basal Metabolic Rate)
description: Calculate your basal metabolic rate and daily calorie needs
metaDescription: Free BMR Calculator - Calculate your Basal Metabolic Rate (calories burned at rest) using Mifflin-St Jeor, Harris-Benedict, and Katch-McArdle formulas. Includes TDEE calculation.
keywords: BMR, basal metabolic rate, BMR calculator, calories at rest, total daily energy expenditure, TDEE, calorie needs, metabolism calculator, Mifflin-St Jeor, Harris-Benedict, weight loss, daily calories

form.ageHelp: Age affects your basal metabolic rate

activity.title: Select your activity level
activity.sedentaryDesc: Little or no exercise, desk job
activity.activeDesc: Daily exercise or intense exercise 3-4 times/week
activity.extraActiveDesc: Very intense daily exercise & physical job

formulas.title: Formula Comparison
formulas.description: Different scientific formulas to calculate your BMR
formulas.mifflinDesc: Most accurate modern formula - Used by the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics
formulas.mifflinFormulaMale: BMR = (10 × weight in kg) + (6.25 × height in cm) - (5 × age) + 5
formulas.mifflinFormulaFemale: BMR = (10 × weight in kg) + (6.25 × height in cm) - (5 × age) - 161
formulas.harrisDesc: Traditional revised formula - Widely used in clinical practice
formulas.katchDesc: Based on lean body mass - More accurate if you know your body fat %
formulas.katchFormula: BMR = 370 + (21.6 × lean body mass in kg)

results.title: Your Results
results.bmrDesc: Calories your body burns at complete rest (24 hours without activity)
results.tdeeDesc: Total calories you burn daily including physical activity
results.formulaComparisonDesc: Different scientific methods to estimate your BMR
results.calorieNeedsDesc: Calories needed based on your physical activity level

info.bmrExplanation: Basal Metabolic Rate (BMR) is the minimum amount of energy (calories) your body needs to maintain vital functions at rest: breathing, blood circulation, cell production, nutrient processing.
info.tdeeExplanation: Total Daily Energy Expenditure (TDEE) is your BMR multiplied by your physical activity level. It represents the total calories you burn in a typical day.
info.useCase2: Lose weight: Consume 300-500 kcal less than TDEE
info.useCase3: Gain weight/muscle: Consume 300-500 kcal more than TDEE
info.accuracyNote: Formulas have a margin of error of ±10%. Mifflin-St Jeor is most accurate for the general population. Katch-McArdle is superior if you know your body composition.

tips.title: Helpful Tips
tips.tip1: Factors that increase BMR: more muscle mass, younger age, male gender, genetics, fever, pregnancy
tips.tip2: Factors that decrease BMR: older age, very restrictive diets, muscle mass loss, hypothyroidism
tips.tip3: Strength training increases muscle mass and therefore your BMR in the long term
tips.tip4: Extreme diets (< 1000 kcal/day) reduce your metabolism as a survival mechanism

disclaimer.title: ⚠️ Important: Limitations
disclaimer.point1: These formulas are estimates based on population averages
disclaimer.point2: They don't consider specific medical conditions (thyroid, PCOS, etc.)
disclaimer.point3: Actual energy expenditure can vary ±10-20% between individuals
disclaimer.point4: Consult with a nutritionist or doctor for a personalized plan
disclaimer.point5: Not recommended for those under 15 without professional supervision

healthAuthority: Source: WHO (World Health Organization), NIH, USDA
